channel.title: Capitalizing Strings
channel.description:
No, I do not mean toUpperCase().
I was trying to turn every single character after a space in a string to capitals.
Like, hello guys, what's up? would return Hello Guys, What's Up?
I've been trying to do this for ages, any help?

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“ziplock, post:17, topic:415381”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=517334.msg3758630#msg3758630 date=1316690951]

I don’t think you understand what I meant. I meant the idea, as in instead of using ‘toLowerCase’ or whatever, using the ASCII values was the fastest method to do this (hence why I said ‘fastest way’, not ‘fastest code’)

You should be more specific next time. Usually when people say ‘fastest way’ they’re saying that particular code is faster than all others.

Anyway, you have a faster snippet to quote next time, lol.

His particular code is faster than all others.

The length of the code is greater.

How do you figure his code is faster than mine?
[/quote]

I bet no one has tested any of them. They’re just going off what other people have said.[/quote]
I’ve tested them…

2093108506ns - mine
18256822483ns - split

That was using 1.6.0_20 64 bit server OpenJDK VM.

Read full topic

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Davidi2:

Ok, then I fail to see the difference in the code (At least enough to warrant a …, as putting things on one line compared to spread out like what Lothy had is completely user preference)

Look before the for loop…

The differences within the for loop are slight, but there are differences.

He does an extra ‘calculation’ to get the previous character, and store it (and he needs to grab something from the array).

Does more explicit casts.

Uses nested if statements for no reason.

Manipulates the current value, stores it, then stores it in the array. I just manipulate and store it straight into the array.

Also, the whole extra part where he makes everything else lowercase.

Sure, these are tiny differences, but you claimed it was the fastest, and it’s not. For all practical purposes, it doesn’t matter, but you claimed it was the fastest.

Here is the average runtime from 10 trials using the 1.6.0_26 client VM (don’t have access to any other VM/machine ATM):
2831447467ns - mine
3301007442ns - his
(They’re even because I’m using the appropriate amount of significant digits)

Here is the code:

[code]import java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService;
import java.util.concurrent.Executors;

public class FastCaps {

private static ExecutorService exec = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(2);

private static final String testName = "p y r o 214 lOL";

public static void main(String[] args) {

	Runnable r1 = new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			System.out.println(capitaliseName(testName));
			long start = System.nanoTime();
			String s = null;
			for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
				s = capitaliseName(testName) + i;
			}
			long end = System.nanoTime();
			System.out.println("T1 Time taken: " + (end - start) + " - "
					+ s);
		}

	};

	Runnable r2 = new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			System.out.println(caps(testName));
			long start = System.nanoTime();
			String s = null;
			for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
				s = caps(testName) + i;
			}
			long end = System.nanoTime();
			System.out.println("T2 Time taken: " + (end - start) + " - "
					+ s);
		}

	};
	exec.execute(r1);
	exec.execute(r2);
	exec.shutdown();
}

public static String caps(String text) {
	char[] cs = text.toCharArray();
	final int len = cs.length;
	char c;
	int last = 32;
	for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
		c = cs[i];
		if (last == 32 && c > 97 && c <= 122) {
			cs[i] = (char) (c - 32);
		} else if (c > 64 && c <= 90) {
			cs[i] = (char) (c + 32);
		}
		last = c;
	}
	return new String(cs);
}

public static String capitaliseName(String name) {
	char[] input = name.toCharArray();
	int prevCharVal;
	int charVal = (int) input[0];
	if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
		charVal -= 32;
		input[0] = (char) charVal;
	}
	for (int i = 1; i < input.length; i++) {
		prevCharVal = (int) input[i - 1];
		charVal = (int) input[i];
		if (prevCharVal == 32) { // A space
			if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
				charVal -= 32;
				input[i] = (char) charVal;
			}
		} else {
			if (charVal >= 65 && charVal <= 90) {
				charVal += 32;
				input[i] = (char) charVal;
			}
		}
	}
	return new String(input);
}

}
[/code]

Here it is without the extra clause (same number of trials, and same machine only a few minutes later):
3123432727ns - mine
3210886228ns - his

Here is the code used:

[code]import java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService;
import java.util.concurrent.Executors;

public class FastCaps {

private static ExecutorService exec = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(2);

private static final String testName = "p y r o 214 lOL";

public static void main(String[] args) {

	Runnable r1 = new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			System.out.println(capitaliseName(testName));
			long start = System.nanoTime();
			String s = null;
			for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
				s = capitaliseName(testName) + i;
			}
			long end = System.nanoTime();
			System.out.println("T1 Time taken: " + (end - start) + " - "
					+ s);
		}

	};

	Runnable r2 = new Runnable() {
		public void run() {
			System.out.println(caps(testName));
			long start = System.nanoTime();
			String s = null;
			for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
				s = caps(testName) + i;
			}
			long end = System.nanoTime();
			System.out.println("T2 Time taken: " + (end - start) + " - "
					+ s);
		}

	};
	exec.execute(r1);
	exec.execute(r2);
	exec.shutdown();
}

public static String caps(String text) {
	char[] cs = text.toCharArray();
	final int len = cs.length;
	char c;
	int last = 32;
	for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
		c = cs[i];
		if (last == 32 && c > 97 && c <= 122) {
			cs[i] = (char) (c - 32);
		}
		last = c;
	}
	return new String(cs);
}

public static String capitaliseName(String name) {
	char[] input = name.toCharArray();
	int prevCharVal;
	int charVal = (int) input[0];
	if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
		charVal -= 32;
		input[0] = (char) charVal;
	}
	for (int i = 1; i < input.length; i++) {
		prevCharVal = (int) input[i - 1];
		charVal = (int) input[i];
		if (prevCharVal == 32) { // A space
			if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
				charVal -= 32;
				input[i] = (char) charVal;
			}
		} else {
			if (charVal >= 65 && charVal <= 90) {
				charVal += 32;
				input[i] = (char) charVal;
			}
		}
	}
	return new String(input);
}

}
[/code]

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Davidi2:

^ Yours doesn’t lowercase other values???

That wasn’t in the spec…

I was trying to turn every single character after a space in a string to capitals.

And to add that you just add the else if…

public static String caps(String text) { char[] cs = text.toCharArray(); final int len = cs.length; char c; int last = 32; for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) { c = cs[i]; if (last == 32 && c > 97 && c <= 122) { cs[i] = (char) (c - 32); } else if(c > 64 && c <= 90) { cs[i] = (char) (c + 32); } last = c; } return new String(cs); }

Scala:

def cap(s: String) = { var s1 = s.capitalize(0).toString s.capitalize.sliding(2).foreach(s => s1 += { if (s(0) == ' ') s(1).toUpper else s(1).toLower }) s1 }

Read full topic

@davidi2 wrote:

^ Yours doesn’t lowercase other values???

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:7, topic:415381”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=480656.msg3525963#msg3525963 date=1299811077]

public class StringCapitaliser {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    String testName = "p y r o 214 lol";
    System.out.println(capitaliseName(testName));
    long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
    for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
      capitaliseName(testName);
    }
    long end = System.currentTimeMillis();
    System.out.println("Time taken: " + (end - start));
  }

  public static String capitaliseName(String name) {
    char[] input = name.toCharArray();

    int prevCharVal;
    int charVal = (int) input[0];
    if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
      charVal -= 32;
      input[0] = (char) charVal;
    }

    for (int i = 1; i < input.length; i++) {
      prevCharVal = (int) input[i - 1];
      charVal = (int) input[i];
      if (prevCharVal == 32) { //A space
        if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
          charVal -= 32;
          input[i] = (char) charVal;
        }
      }
      else {
        if (charVal >= 65 && charVal <= 90) {
          charVal += 32;
          input[i] = (char) charVal;
        }
      }
    }
    return new String(input);
  }
}

[/quote]

This is the fastest way to do it, even if the code is a bit longer.[/quote]

…

public static String caps(String text) { char[] cs = text.toCharArray(); final int len = cs.length; char c; int last = 32; for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) { c = cs[i]; if (last == 32 && c > 97 && c <= 122) { cs[i] = (char) (c - 32); } last = c; } return new String(cs); }

Also, this is how I would do it in Scala:

def cap(s: String) = { var s1 = s.capitalize(0).toString s.capitalize.sliding(2).foreach(s => s1 += { if (s(0) == ' ') s(1).toUpper else s(1) }) s1 }

I’d probably skip on some of the flexabilities that allow the logic portion to be on one line, but that would just be for clairity…

Also, it’s the same logic behind it, just more concisely done.

Read full topic

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:20, topic:384891”][code=java]
public class StringCapitaliser {

public static void main(String[] args) {
String testName = “p y r o 214 lol”;
System.out.println(capitaliseName(testName));
long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
capitaliseName(testName);
}
long end = System.currentTimeMillis();
System.out.println("Time taken: " + (end - start));
}

public static String capitaliseName(String name) {
char[] input = name.toCharArray();

int prevCharVal;
int charVal = (int) input[0];
if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
  charVal -= 32;
  input[0] = (char) charVal;
}

for (int i = 1; i < input.length; i++) {
  prevCharVal = (int) input[i - 1];
  charVal = (int) input[i];
  if (prevCharVal == 32) { //A space
    if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
      charVal -= 32;
      input[i] = (char) charVal;
    }
  }
  else {
    if (charVal >= 65 && charVal <= 90) {
      charVal += 32;
      input[i] = (char) charVal;
    }
  }
}
return new String(input);

}
}
[/code][/quote]

This is the fastest way to do it, even if the code is a bit longer.

Read full topic

item.title: Capitalizing Strings
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“vortex, post:3, topic:415381”] String in = "hello capitalized strings"; String out = ""; for(String tmp : in.split(" ")) out += tmp.substring(0, 1).toUpperCase() + tmp.substring(1, tmp.length()) + " "; out = out.trim();
Definitely da best way to do it[/quote]

public String toTitle(String in)
{
String out = "";

for(String tmp : in.split(" "))
  out += tmp.toUpperCase() + " ";

out = out.trim();

return out;
}

// proposed idea, being part of the string class that extends String
public void toTitleCase()
{
 String out = "";
 
 for(String tmp : this.split(" "))
  out += tmp.toUpperCase() + " ";

this = out.trim();
}

i was thinking can u make a string class that extends String(i mean thats what OOP exists right?)? so u could add extra functionality to strings like this then u could just use strObj.toTitleCase() instead of toTitle(strObj).

Read full topic
